Department of Chemistry Sadakathullah Appa College Madurai Kamaraj University Rahmath Nagar Tirunelveli Tamilnadu India aDepartment of Chemistry, Sadakathullah Appa College, Rahmath Nagar, Tirunelveli , Tamilnadu, India b Department of Natural Products Chemistry, School of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai, Tamilnadu, India. Department of Natural Products Chemistry School of Chemistry Madurai Kamaraj University Madurai Tamilnadu India bDepartment of Natural Products Chemistry, School of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai, Tamilnadu, India c Vice Chancellor, Manonmaniam Sundaranar University, Tirunelveli, Tamilnadu, India. Vice Chancellor Manonmaniam Sundaranar University Tirunelveli Tamilnadu India cVice Chancellor, Manonmaniam Sundaranar University, Tirunelveli, Tamilnadu, India ⁎ Corresponding author. An ionic Cu(I) complex (Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD), stabilized by water soluble quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD) with an 8-N-pentyl side chain, was prepared and characterized by ESI-Mass, NMR and UV-Visible spectroscopies and also molecular modeling studies. The synthesized Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD was found to be highly efficient in promoting A3-coupling reaction of various aldehydes, amines and terminal alkynes to yield propargylamines in acetonitrile medium. The prepared Qun-β-CD (C) alone, without any metal ion, follows a different course exhibiting excellent catalytic efficiency in an intramolecular tandem cyclisation reaction of the same reagents to yield quinolines in aqueous medium. From the point of the environmental concerns, the work presented here has the merits of both three-component reaction, environmentally friendliness, easy separation, simple work-up, good yields, the avoidance of organic solvents and use of an inexpensive catalyst. The catalyst was recycled more than five consecutive cycles without any significant loss in its activity in both reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ionic quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin Cu(i) complex A3 coupling Aqueous medium Metal free tandem cyclisation 1 Introduction Environmentally benign, economical, and efficient catalysts, with easy separation and reuse have become increasingly important in the chemical community [1,2]. This approach helps in the reduction of raw materials usage, energy requirements of process and products, to diminish or eliminate harmful chemicals into the environment [3,4], to use renewable resources to extend the robustness and recyclability [5]. One such dimension in this direction is design of catalytic domino processes [6] which allow reduction in the overall time required to obtain the desired product, solvents and energy saving, and reduction of waste production [7]. Different combination including metal/organo [8,9], metal enzyme [10], organo/organo [11] and metal/metal catalyst [12] systems have been exploited for this purpose. Propargylamines are synthetically versatile and key intermediates for the preparation of many nitrogen containing biologically active compounds, such as β-lactams, oxo-tromosine analogues, conformationally restricted peptides, isosteres and therapeutics drug molecules [13]. Three-component reactions of an aldehyde, an amine and an alkyene, known as A3-coupling, represent a worthwhile approach to synthesis of propargylamine. The most popular A3-coupling reaction are based on coinage metals namely silver [14], and gold [15,16], too, and other metals such as iron [17], indium [18], nickel, [19], cobalt [20], and Au-MOF [21], have also demonstrated their skill to catalyze this transformation. In this context, copper based catalysts, are most frequently used catalytic systems [22]. Fused heterocyclic compounds are structural elements, frequently encountered in many natural products and biomolecules. Among them, the quinoline moiety is present extensively in naturally occurring and biologically active compounds [23,24], and also shows interestingly photochemical properties. Consequently, the synthesis of quinolines has been extensively pursued over the years. Examples include Skarup-Doebner-Ven Miller [25], and Friedlander [26] syntheses, while very effective, these syntheses involve use of a variety of traditional Lewis and Bronsted acids, which are not environmentally compatible, producing large amount of wastes and require longer reaction times. Therefore, the design of an improved and environmentally benign approach for their preparation is desirable. Cyclodextrins (CDs), as simple naturally occurring macrocyclic oligosaccharides, possess a hydrophobic cavity that selectively bind substrates and catalyze chemical reactions through formation of host–guest complexes via noncovalent interactions [27,28]. Modification of cyclodextrins offers enormous opportunities for chemists [29–31], ranging from achieving solubility in a desired solvent to selective and specific catalysis. Highly water soluble cyclodextrins are also desirable in applications such as drug formulation, controlled release studies etc., [32]. In addition, modified cyclodextrins act as ligands for various metal ions [33–38]. Our continuing interest in developing greener methods for the synthesis of useful bioactive compounds, prompted us to successfully utilize per-6-amino-β-cyclodextrin, and pyridinium modified β-cyclodextrin as useful catalysts as well as hosts for selective organic transformations [39–41]. Encouraged by these efforts and aiming further to demonstrate the efficiency and generality of these modified cyclodextrins as catalysts/hosts, a novel quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD, Scheme 1 ) is synthesized. Qun-β-CD (C)is soluble in water and is found to exhibit excellent catalytic activity in A3 coupling and tandem cyclization reactions (in the presence and absence of Cu(I), respectively) from simple and easily available starting materials under milder reaction conditions,. The observed results are discussed below. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. All chemicals were used as commercially available without further purification unless otherwise noted. NMR spectra were recorded at 300 MHz on a Bruker spectrometer. All 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured in DMSO‑d6 and CDCl3 with TMS as the internal standard. FT-IR spectral analyzes were performed using a JASCO FT/IR-410 instrument by the KBr pellet technique in the range of 4000–500 cm−1. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) analyzes were recorded in LCQ Fleet, Thermo Fisher Instruments Limited, US. ESI-MS was performed in negative ion mode. 2.1 General procedure for synthesis of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) A solution of NaH (29.3 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (8 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 8-aminoquinoline (14.7 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (8 mL). The reaction medium was then heated at 90 °C for 1 h. A gray color was observed afterwards, a solution of 1-Cl-Pentane (14.7 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (10 mL) is added and the reaction medium was heated at 90 °C for 48 h. Color of the mixture changed from gray to brown. 1,4-Dioxane is then removed in vaccum and 125 mL water is added. The product was extracted with 3 × 25 mL of ethyl acetate, brown color liquid was observed which was analyzed by NMR spectroscopy (300 MHz, CDCl3, T = 300 K, TMS = 0 ppm) and ESI-MS. 2.2 Synthesis of quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD (C)) Quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD (C)) was synthesised using a modified cyclodextrin protocol described by K. Pitchumani et al., (Qun-β-CD (C)) [42]. 2.3 General procedure for A3 coupling reaction between aldehydes, amine and acetylenes (4a-l) A reaction tube equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD (C)) (0.003 mmol, 2 mol%) and Cu(I) (0.003 mmol, 2 mol%) dispersed in ACN (3 mL) for 15 min, then aldehyde (1 mmol), amine (1.2 mmol) and alkyne (1.2 mmol) were added. The tube was then stoppered. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. After completion of the reaction, the product was extracted with ethyl acetate and water system using separating funnel, collect the organic layer, dried with sodium sulfate, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting crude product was purified by passing it through a column of silica gel 60–120 mesh using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (9:1 ratio) as the eluent, affording corresponding product, which was analyzed by NMR spectroscopy (300 MHz and 400 MHz, CDCl3, T = 300 K, TMS = 0 ppm), FT-IR and ESI-MS. After extraction of the product, the quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin was present in the water layer, which was subsequently reused. 2.4 General procedure for tandem cyclisation reaction between aldehydes, amine and acetylenes (5a-5l) A reaction tube equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD (C)) (0.013 mmol, 5 mol%) dispersed in water (3 mL) for 15 min. then aldehyde (1 mmol), amine (1.2 mmol) and alkyne (1.2 mmol) were added. The tube was then stoppered. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. After completion of the reaction, the product was extracted with ethyl acetate, filtered, dried with sodium sulfate, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting crude product was purified by passing it through a column of silica gel 60–120 mesh using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (9:1 ratio) as the eluent, affording corresponding product, which was analyzed by NMR spectroscopy (300 MHz and 400 MHz, CDCl3, T = 300 K, TMS = 0 ppm), FT-IR and ESI-MS. After extraction of the product, the quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin was present in the water layer, which was subsequently reused. 2.5 General procedure for recording ESI-MS spectra for formation of cu(i)@qun-β-cd A reaction tube equipped with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD (C)) (0.003 mmol, 2 mol%) and Cu(I) (0.003 mmol, 2 mol%) dispersed in ACN (3 mL) for 30 min at room temperature. After completion of 30 min the reaction mixture was collected and its ESI-MS spectrum was immediately recorded for Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Qun-β-CD (C) The synthetic pathway to obtain Qun-β-CD (C) is shown in Scheme 1. Mono-6-tosyl-β-cyclodextrin (A) was prepared via tosylation from commercially available β-cyclodextrin. Subsequent reaction with N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) followed by anion-exchange on amberlite Cl− resin afforded the desired amphiphilic Qun-β-CD (C) as a brown solid, which was stable towards oxygen and moisture. The synthesis of Qun-β-CD (C) was achieved in a single step straight-forward reaction between A and B with 72% yield. The structures of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) and Qun-β-CD (C) were confirmed from 1H and 13C NMR, Mass spectra and Elemental analyzes. The synthesis of Qun-β-CD (C) was also confirmed from its ESI-MS spectra (Fig. 1 a) which shows an m/z peak at 1333.24 corresponding to [M + 1 adduct]. In the complexation of Qun-β-CD (C) with Cu(I), the peak at 1333.24 disappeared and a new peak appeared (Fig. 1b) at 1521.21 (m/z), which corresponds to the adduct of Qun-β-CD (C) with Cu(I) (cal: m/z = 1521.21 and obs: m/z = 1522.36 for [M+Cu(I)+1]+). The formation of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) and Qun-β-CD (C), was confirmed from the 1H and 13C NMR spectra of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) in CDCl3 (Figs. S1 and S2) and Qun-β-CD (C), recorded in DMSO‑d6 (Figs. S4 and S5). The proton chemical shifts for (i) N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B)and (ii) Qun-β-CD (C) are shown in Table 1 . From the Table 1, it is clear that there are considerable downfield shifts for the alkyl and aromatic protons (a to k) of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B), when it is modified with cyclodextrin. The 13C NMR chemical shifts of Qun-β-CD (C) undergo substantial shifts, also providing support for binding of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) to form Qun-β-CD (C).Additional evidence was obtained from the new peaks at 121 to 147 ppm which correspond to the aromatic protons of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine (B) after modification with β-cyclodextrin (Fig. S5). To identify the potential spatial proximities among the different protons of Qun-β-CD (C), a two-dimensional NOESY-NMR experiment (Fig. 2 ) was also carried out. Cross-contours between β-CD and pentyl protons are absent in 2D-NOESY spectra, when the aromatic protons of quinoline, aliphatic protons of pentyl group and the cyclodextrin protons are not correlated, which indicate that the quinoline moiety and the pentyl side chain are not included into the hydrophobic cavity of β-CD. Energy minimization studies are also carried out using molecular modeling to understand the possible inclusion of pentyl side chain of Qun-β-CD (C) in the β-CD cavity. From the results shown in Table 2 (Supporting information), it is clear that mode A in which pentyl group is present outside the Qun-β-CD (C) cavity is more favored than that of inclusion of pentyl group inside the Qun-β-CD (C) cavity (Mode B), and the details are given in Figs. S9 and 10 in SI. The solubility of Qun-β-CD (C) in water is very high, compared to native β-CD. The solubility of Qun-β-CD (C) in water is found to be 0.9 mmol in 4 mL of water at room temperature (Fig. S8a in SI). The UV–Vis absorption spectrum, of Qun-β-CD (C) shows a peak at 360 nm, which corresponds to quinoline moiety in Qun-β-CD (C). Details are given in Fig. S8b in supporting information. The synthesized Qun-β-CD (C), in the presence of Cu(I) ion, acts as an efficient catalyst in A3 coupling reaction of aromatic aldehydes, amines and alkynes to yield propargylamines. Without Cu(I), Qun-β-CD (C) alone, follows a different catalytic route in promoting tandem cyclisation of the same aldehydes, amines and alkynes to yield quinolines. Structures of the products are confirmed by their melting point, NMR, UV-Vis and IR spectra. The observed results are discussed below. 3.2 Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD catalyzed A3 coupling reaction Behavior of the copper complex of Qun-β-CD is screened in the synthesis of propargylamines as follows. To determine the best reaction conditions (i.e., effect of solvent, copper species in Qun-β-CD (C) catalyst, and reaction time), required for good yields of propargylamines, preliminary studies are carried out using 4-bromobenzaldehyde, aniline and phenylacetylene as model substrates and the results are summarized in Table 3 . Without Cu(I) and β-CD, there is no reaction (Table 3, entry 1). However, with only Cu(I) or β-CD@Cu(I), the yield is very low (Table 3, entries 2 and 3). Various ligands are used, and among them, Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD catalyst gives good yields (Table 3, entries 4–5). For solvent-screening studies, a mixture of 4-bromobenzaldehyde (1 mmol), aniline (1.2 mmol), phenylacetylene (1.2 mmol), and the corresponding Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD catalyst is stirred at different temperatures in 2 mL of a suitable solvent. Interestingly, when solvents such as water or DMSO are used for this model reaction, only poor to moderate yields of the desired product are obtained. Table 3 shows that acetonitrile, is the most promising one as excellent yield of the desired A3 coupling product is obtained (Table 3, entries 6 to 10). Temperature variation studies show that yield of the desired products is in fact higher at room temperature (Table 3, entry 10). The corresponding Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD catalyst is stirred at different times until completion of the reaction (as monitored by GC and TLC) and, 1 h is sufficient enough to give the products in good yield (Table 3, entries 10 and 11). Catalyst loading is also optimized and in the absence of Qun-β-CD, there was no reaction and product formation is effective at a low loading level of Cu(I) (0.2 mol%) and Qun-β-CD (0.2 mol%) (Table 3, entry 12). To examine the scope of this three-component coupling reaction, the studies are extended to different combinations of aldehydes, amines and alkynes. The observed results are listed in Table 4 . Different substituted aldehydes containing both electron-donating or electron-withdrawing groups such as, methyl, methoxy, chloro and bromo groups (Table 4, entries 4a to 4d) have yielded the analogous products in good yields at room temperature. In order to expand the scope to acetylenic substrates, a combination of benzaldehyde/aniline/acetylenes is chosen, and various acetylenes are examined. Aliphatic cyclic and acyclic amines, have displayed high reactivity under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 4, entries 4g and 4h). Aromatic acetylenes have also afforded the corresponding products in good yields. Subsequently, a variety of amines are also examined and as seen in Table 4 aromatic amines such as, aniline, 2-iodoaniline, 4-bromoaniline and 2-aminopyridine, also undergo the three-component coupling smoothly and have generated the corresponding products in good yields (Table 4, entries 4i to 4l). Thus the present method offers the following competitive advantages: (i) recyclability of the catalyst without significant loss of its catalytic activity; (ii) use of a readily available, cheap copper catalyst without further purification, or without using other additives; (iii) lower catalyst loading (0.2 mol%); (iv) broad substrate applicability; (v) high yields in short reaction times; and (vi) simple and easy operation. 3.3 Qun-β-CD (C) catalysed tandem cyclization reaction When the three component coupling reaction of arylaldehyde, amine and phenylacetylene is carried out in the presence of Qun-β-CD (C) without Cu(I) ion, the reaction takes a different course and an intramolecular tandem cyclisation occurs yielding quinolines as end products. Preliminary investigations have indicated that a small excess of aniline and benzaldehyde (1.2 equiv. of both) with respect to phenylacetylene are required to obtain optimum yields of the product and the conversion is lower when equimolar amounts of all the reactants are used. Further increase in the molar amounts (1.5 equiv.) of aniline and benzaldehyde with respect to phenylacetylene does not improve the yields, but rather has resulted in side reactions. Without ligand and with only β-CD, there is no reaction (Table 5 , entries 1 and 2). However, with only (B), the yield is very low (entry 3). On the other hand the yield has improved significantly when Qun-β-CD is used as catalyst. For solvent-screening studies, a mixture of 4-bromobenzaldehyde (1.2 mmol), aniline (1.2 mmol), phenylacetylene (1 mmol), and the corresponding Qun-β-CD (C) ligand are stirred at different temperatures in 2 mL of a suitable solvent until the completion of the reaction (as monitored by GC and TLC). Table 5 shows that water is the most promising one as excellent yields of the desired tandem cyclisation product is obtained (entries 4 to 9). Interestingly, when solvents such as DMF, or DMSO are used, only poor to moderate yields are obtained. As can be deduced from Table 5, the reaction is dependent more on temperature than on solvent polarity. Indeed, reaction yields are higher even also at room temperature (entries 10 and 11) than at heating using water as solvent. Catalyst loading is also optimized and in the absence of Qun-β-CD (C), there was no reaction and product formation is effective only at a loading level of 0.5 mol% Qun-β-CD (C). After identifying the optimized reactions conditions, our attention is turned towards studying the scope of the method. A wide variety of substituted aldehydes are used to synthesize quinolines and the results are summarized in Table 6 . As the data indicate, all the substituted aldehydes give the products in good yields. Both 2- and 4-substituted aldehydes readily undergo the reaction sequence, and only a moderate substituent effect is observed. To further widen the applicability of the procedure, a variety of arylacetylenes, aldehydes and amines are tested and Table 6 summarizes the observed results of the synthesis of quinolines. The results show that all the reactions give the expected products in good yields. Substituted acetylenes (Table 6, entries 5e to 5h) react efficiently, showing only a moderate substituent effect. The procedure is also extended to aliphatic amines, and the product is also obtained in good yield (Table 6, entries 5g and 5h). Encouraged by these results, the scope of the methodology is also extended to a variety of substituted anilines, benzaldehydes and terminal phenylacetylenes. It is worthmentioning that when different anilines containing groups such as chloro, and bromo substituents (entries 5i and 5j), are used, the products are obtained in good yield at short reaction time. Interestingly, 2-aminopyridine and 2-aminopyrene also give good yields (entries 5k and 5l) in water. On the basis of the above results, and also in accordance with previous literature reports,31 plausible mechanisms for A3 coupling (route A) and tandem cyclization (route B) reactions, as shown in Scheme 2 , are proposed. Route A: The Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD complex (I) is formed in situ through the addition of Cu(I) to Qun-β-CD (C), via coordination between the –OH groups of β-CD, -NH group of N-pentylquinolin-8-amine(B) and Cu(I). This is supported by the observation of a strong peak at 1522.36 for ([M+Cu(I)+Cl−]+) (Fig. 1), which corresponds to the complex of Qun-β-CD and Cu(I). In the absence of any base, however, Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD complex reacts very easily with terminal alkyne to give copper acetylide intermediate (II). This liberates acid, which protonates the lignad causing partial decomplexation, based on the result a tentative mechanism was proposed [16]: first the Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD form the Π-complex (II) with alkyne 3. This increase the acidity of acetylenic hydrogen which is removed by the Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD to give a copper acetylide (III). The proton assited condensation between amine 2 and aldehyde 1 generate a molecule of water and the iminium intermediate 4, which reacts with copper acetylide (III) to afford the desired propargylamine and regenerate the catalyst. Route B: In the absence of Cu(I), an alternative pathway is involved. The proposed mechanism (route B) for the synthesis of 2,4-diarylquinolines from anilines, benzaldehydes and phenylacetylenes is illustrated in Scheme 2. [43] We propose that an inclusion complex is formed through the addition of aldimine to Qun-β-CD, which is formed intermediate(IV), which is attacked by phenylacetylene to give propargylamine (V), which is undergoes cyclisation followed by oxidative aromatization in presence of Qun-β-CD to give 2,4-diarylquinoline. We proposed that the attack of acetylene on the in situ-generated imine could be facilitated by a Lewis acid activation of the imine to give propargylamine. When the imine is formed, it undergo inclusion complex with Qun-β-CD it remains bound to the Lewis acid center to further exploit the reactivity of its δ+ carbonyl carbon. This is followed by the nucleophilic attack of ortho- position of the aniline on the alkyne to close the ring, giving cyclic intermediate 5, and this intermediate undergoes rearrangement to give dihydroquinoline intermediate 6. Final oxidative aromatization in presence of air gives the end product 2,4- diarylquinolines. To provide additional support for the proposed mechanism, energy minimization studies are carried out on the reactants, intermediates formed during the reaction and the product in both A3 coupling with Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD and tandem cyclisation with Qun-β-CD (C) alone. The data, given in Table 7 , indicate clearly that when the reaction takes place in Qun-β-CD (C), the ΔE changes for the various steps (I-V) proposed in both routes A and B in Scheme 2. Molecular modeling studies in A3-coupling reaction (route A) and tandem reactions involving free energy changes in reactant, intermediate and product during the reaction process are also carried out, to provide additional support for the proposed reaction mechanism. The data involving Qun-β-CD and Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD in A3 coupling reaction given in Table 7, indicate clearly a more significant role for copper. The ΔE for the overall heat of product formation using Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD is more favored (ΔE = −87.2 kcal. M−1) than Qun-β-CD alone (ΔE = −84.4 kcal. M−1). In fact, the changes in ΔE is more significant in all steps, when Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD is used as a catalyst in A3 coupling reaction indicating clearly that Qun-β-CD is essential. This may be attributed to binding of nitrogen to Cu which promotes A3 coupling more significantly. After the completion of the reaction, resulting in expulsion of product from Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD cavity and the reaction cycle goes on. In Table 7 also indicate to important role of Qun-β-CD for the formation of tandem reaction. The ΔE value is clearly indicates more significant role of Qun-β-CD. Support for the preferential inclusion the aldimine to Qun-β-CD (C) to form IV and V (in route B), obtained from energy minimization studies. Probable inclusions of aldimine into Qun-β-CD to form intermediate V (ΔE = −90.2 kcal. M−1), clearly indicate important role to promotes tandem cyclisation reaction more significantly. After the formation of the final product, resulting expulsion of product from Qun-β-CD cavity and the reaction cycles goes on further reusability, detailed images are given in supporting information as S11and 12. The formation of propargylamine is also evidenced from absorbance spectra (Fig. S13a). To further confirm the formation of products such as, propargylamines and quinolines, FT-IR spectra is recorded (Fig. S13b), and this clearly indicates that –NH band for propargylamines is observed at 3323 cm−1 (brown) and absence of –NH band for quinolines products at same region (rose). While homogenous catalysts are more active and selective than heterogeneous catalysts (known for their easy recycling), in the present study the separation of these homogenous catalysis from product and catalyst recycling is effected using simple separation process [68]. In order to demonstrate the stability and recyclability of the Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD, the catalyst is reused for the A3 coupling reaction under optimized conditions upto 5 times and also for tandem cyclisation when Qun-β-CD (C) alone is used. The catalyst is stable in air and also shows good conversion upto five cycles without any significant loss of its activity (Fig. 3 a–c). Even after five reaction cycles, the product yield remains 94%. The reaction conditions, solvent, temperature, TON, TOF and reusability of the various other reported catalysts employed earlier for the A3 coupling and tandem cyclisation reactions of aldehydes, amines and alkynes are given in Table 8 . Comparison of the results indicates that our catalytic system (entries19 and 31) exhibits better catalytic activity and give better TON and TOF than other systems. On the other hand, the previously reported systems require organic solvents, higher reaction temperature and higher reaction time thus demonstrating that the present catalytic system (entries 19 and 31) act as a better catalyst in view of its environmently friendliness and economy, in both these three-component reactions, other sustainable advantage include easy separation, simple work-up, good yields, the avoidance of organic solvents, good TON, TOF value and use of an inexpensive catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, a novel, ionic, quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin, Qun-β-CD (C) with an 8-N-pentyl side chain is developed, and the prepared catalyst is well characterized by NMR, ESI Mass spectrometry, FT-IR, UV-Visible spectroscopy and also molecular modeling. This Qun-β-CD (C) is utilised as an effective supramolecular ligand for Cu(I) ion and is found to be highly efficient in promoting A3-coupling reaction of various aldehydes, amines and terminal alkynes to yield propargylamines via CH activation in acetonitrile medium. The prepared Qun-β-CD (C) alone, without any metal ion, follows a different course exhibiting excellent catalytic efficiency in an intramolecular tandem cyclisation reaction of the same reagents to yield quinolines via CH activation in aqueous medium. The work presented here has considerable greens advances, namely merits of three-component reaction, environmentally friendliness, easy separation, simple work-up, good yields, the avoidance of organic solvents and use of inexpensive catalyst. Thus the applications of this Qun-β-CD (C) catalysed, multifunctional approach reported in this study can be extended to the synthesis of other important medicinal scaffolds, such as pyrazoles, oxazolinones, benzodiazepines, quinoxalinones and possibly other heterocycles. Significance of the present work In recent times, environmental requirements have pressed chemists to develop clean catalytic processes and technologies. In this context, homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysis in aqueous phase is a very promising environmentally friendly protocol. Among the different approaches proposed, the use of cyclodextrins (CDs), a class of naturally occurring are cyclic oligosaccharide receptors comprising of d-glucopyranose units, proves to be very promising. In recent years, modified cyclodextrins play an important role in the field of catalysis due to their advantages such as, increase in rate and selectivity, water-solublity, stabilization of catalytically active noble metal nanoparticles in water Propargylamines are synthetically versatile and key intermediates for the preparation of many nitrogen containing biologically active compounds, such as β-lactams, oxo-tromosine analogues, conformationally restricted peptides, isosteres and therapeutics drug molecules. Three-component reactions of an aldehyde, an amine and an alkyene, known as A3-coupling, represents a worthwhile approach to synthesis of propargylamine. Fused heterocyclic compounds are structural elements, frequently encountered in many natural products and biomolecules. Among them, the quinoline moiety is present extensively in naturally occurring and biologically active compounds, and also shows interestingly photochemical properties. Consequently, the synthesis of quinolines has been extensively pursued over the years. For the first time, we have developed a novel, ionic, ionic Cu(I) complex (Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD), stabilized by water soluble quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD) with an 8-N-pentyl side chain, was prepared and characterized by ESI-Mass, NMR and UV-Visible spectroscopies and also molecular modeling studies. The synthesized Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD was found to be highly efficient in promoting A3-coupling reaction of various aldehydes, amines and terminal alkynes to yield propargylamines via CH activation in acetonitrile medium. The prepared Qun-β-CD (C) alone, without any metal ion, follows a different course exhibiting excellent catalytic efficiency in an intramolecular tandem cyclisation reaction of the same reagents to yield quinolines via CH activation in aqueous medium. In the three-component, room temperature, atom economical reactions, the catalyst was recycled more than six consecutive cycles without any loss in its activity. For those reasons, this manuscript is suitable for publication in Journal of Molecular Catalysis. Declaration of Competing Interest None. coredata.dc:description: An ionic Cu(I) complex (Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD), stabilized by water soluble quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin (Qun-β-CD) with an 8-N-pentyl side chain, was prepared and characterized by ESI-Mass, NMR and UV-Visible spectroscopies and also molecular modeling studies. The synthesized Cu(I)@Qun-β-CD was found to be highly efficient in promoting A3-coupling reaction of various aldehydes, amines and terminal alkynes to yield propargylamines in acetonitrile medium. The prepared Qun-β-CD (C) alone, without any metal ion, follows a different course exhibiting excellent catalytic efficiency in an intramolecular tandem cyclisation reaction of the same reagents to yield quinolines in aqueous medium. From the point of the environmental concerns, the work presented here has the merits of both three-component reaction, environmentally friendliness, easy separation, simple work-up, good yields, the avoidance of organic solvents and use of an inexpensive catalyst. The catalyst was recycled more than five consecutive cycles without any significant loss in its activity in both reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Quinolinium modified β-cyclodextrin: An ionic ligand towards sustainable A3-coupling and tandem cyclisation reactions of aldehydes, amines and alkynes
